question: Determine the total power dissipation in watts for a parallel circuit comprising $6  \Omega$, $12  \Omega$, and $4  \Omega$ resistors connected across a $12$-volt automotive battery, then utilize this determined value alongside the given specifications that standard automotive lead-acid batteries exhibit $48  \text{Ah}$ capacity and enforce a mandatory $50\%$ depth-of-discharge restriction to compute the practical operational runtime in hours.
subject: physics
constant_ev: Use 12 volts as the battery voltage when calculating total power dissipation
Assume 50% depth-of-discharge limit for lead-acid automotive batteries when calculating practical runtime
Use 48 Ah as typical capacity for 12V automotive batteries when determining usable capacity
derived_ev: The equivalent resistance calculated using the parallel resistance formula is 2.0 ohms
The equivalent resistance of the circuit is 2 ohms
The total power dissipation is 72.0 watts
The total power dissipated in the circuit when connected to a 12-volt automotive battery is 72 W
The usable battery capacity considering the 50% depth-of-discharge restriction is 24 Ah
The theoretical runtime with full 48 Ah battery capacity would be 8 hours
The practical runtime of the circuit using a standard automotive battery with 50% depth-of-discharge restriction is 4.0 hours

The solver's step-by-step calculations are all correct, properly applying parallel resistance formulas, Ohm's law, power equations, and the specified battery constraints, so there is no ambiguity.
